Focus and Topic Constructions This section considers two types of constructions which draw attention to a particular element. We will consider topics first since they have greater scope and therefore occur outside of focus constructions.
Example 1 shows that a single sentence may have both a topic phrase and a focus phrase. In this case, the topic Bill is introduced by the topic marker as for, and the focus phrase soccer, which has been moved from its normal position after the verb, follows the topic phrase.
As for Bill, soccer he plays __ best.
As defined here, constructions consist of a topic phrase followed by a complete sentence or question and usually set apart by a comma. Certain marker words or phrases may also be used to set off topics, as shown in the following English examples:
As for John, I think he will make a good doctor. Speaking of Jill, where is she?

In the lexicon, add the feature topic-initial to the topic markers which can only appear before the topic itself. Add the feature topic-final to the topic markers which can only appear after the topic itself. Do not add either feature to topic markers which can appear on either side of the topic. In the lexicon, add the feature makeTopicM to each topic marker to change the category for the syntax. (If the word can also be used in other ways, make a separate entry for each use.) If the marker is a phrase, such as ‘as for’ or ‘speaking of’ in English, you will need to key them as a single entry with an underscore between the words and use the Join Compound program within CARLA Studio.
Key the topic marker clitic(s) your language uses in the following box, with an equal sign to show which side it attaches to the topic phrase on.
In the lexicon, add the feature topic_prefix to each topic marker proclitic and the feature topic_suffix to each topic marker enclitic.
Key the topic marker affix(es) your language uses in the following box, with a hyphen to show which side it attaches to the head noun on.
In the lexicon, add the feature topic to each topic marker affix.
Note that the comma is important in topic constructions and may be useful in disambiguating topics from other types of constructions. As mentioned in
Coordination Constructions - Lists and Appositives, you can choose to make the comma (,) a word-formation character in CarlaStudio. Then make it a suffix or enclitic that can go on any word category and give it the feature comma. The PC-Patr grammar constraints to disambiguate via commas are already provided, but you will need to activate them by removing the comment character in the S rule(s) including a TopicP.
In contrast, while constructions also have an element fronted which may be set off by punctuation, the phrase in focus is moved from its normal position in the sentence, leaving a gap. Certain markers, such as ‘only’ in English, may be used to mark the focused phrase. Focus constructions are not used frequently in SVO languages, since the subject is usually in focus and is already first in the normal order. Other word orders, such as VSO languages, may make extensive use of focus constructions. English examples of focus constructions include:
Girls, I like __. Soccer, Bill plays __ best. Only that boy, Jerry hit __ .
